member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.ClockState
member.summary: Describes the potential states of a timeline's Clock object.

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.ClockState.Active
member.summary: The current Clock time changes in direct relation to that of its parent. If the timeline is an animation, it is actively affecting targeted properties, so their value may change from tick (a sampling point in time) to tick. If the timeline has children, they may be Active, Filling, or Stopped.

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.ClockState.Filling
member.summary: The Clock timing continues, but does not change in relation to that of its parent. If the timeline is an animation, it is actively affecting targeted properties, but its values don't change from tick to tick. If the timeline has children, they may be Active, Filling, or Stopped.

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.ClockState.Stopped
member.summary: The Clock timing is halted, making the clock's current time and progress values undefined. If this timeline is an animation, it no longer affects targeted properties. If this timeline has children, they are also Stopped.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.CubicEase
member.summary: Represents an easing function that creates an animation that accelerates and/or decelerates using the formula f(t) = t^3.

member.summary: Gets or sets the current Easing Mode

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.EasingMode.EaseIn
member.summary: Interpolation follows the mathematical formula associated with the easing function.

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.EasingMode.EaseOut
member.summary: Interpolation follows 100% interpolation minus the output of the formula associated with the easing function.

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.EasingMode.EaseInOut
member.summary: Interpolation uses EaseIn for the first half of the animation and EaseOut for the second half.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.EasingFunctions
member.summary: Easing functions allow you to apply custom mathematical formulas to your animations. For example, you may want an object to realistically bounce or behave as though it were on a spring. You could use Key-Frame or even From/To/By animations to approximate these effects but it would take a significant amount of work and the animation would be less accurate than using a mathematical formula.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.ElasticEase
member.summary: Represents an easing function that creates an animation that resembles a spring oscillating back and forth until it comes to rest.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.FillBehavior
member.summary: Specifies how a Timeline behaves when it is outside its active period but its parent is inside its active or hold period.

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.FillBehavior.HoldEnd
member.summary: After it reaches the end of its active period, the timeline holds its progress until the end of its parent's active and hold periods.

member.name: F:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.FillBehavior.Stop
member.summary: The timeline stops if it is outside its active period while its parent is inside its active period.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Animation.IEasingFunction
member.summary: Interface for creating custom Easing Function

member.summary: Represents a that has just logic, updatable through the Update() method.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Behavior.Family
member.summary: Gets or sets the . Every behavior is initialized with Family set to Default. Default behaviors are updated first, and any other behaviors with different values are updated in a second row. Families that are not Default are updated in parallel (the list of of each is updated in a non-deterministic secuencial order). For example: if a game had three behaviors marked as "AI" and two marked as "Physics", it would launch two threads: one to update the AI behaviors and another to update the Physics ones. See for more information.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Component
member.summary: Provides logic and functionality to an .
member.remarks:
A should 1) solve just a single problem (provide a position, render a mesh, hold a mesh, ...) and 2) depend on other instances to provide more complex behaviors.
For implementers
The method Initialize allows you to perform custom logic when a is initializated.
The method ResolveDependencies is used to make sure the component has all the dependencies it needs to work.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.Rectangle
member.summary:
Gets or sets the rectangle where the owner entity is placed.
Such rectangle is modified by other components in scenarios like animated sprites, where its value depend on the sprite to be rendered on each moment. It then can be used to limit the area of the texture to be drawn.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.LocalDrawOrder
member.summary: Gets or sets the draw order (%) in local space. It's included in [0, 1] where 0 represents the closest position to the camera, and 1 the farthest. The draw order is also "contained" in layers, so the order on these last ones act prior to this value (i.e. an instance with draw order 1 in GUI layer will be always drawn closer than another one with draw order 0 in Alpha, as GUI layer is before than Alpha one).

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.Effect
member.summary: Gets or sets the sprite effect.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.GlobalOpacity
member.summary: Gets the global opacity. It's included in [0, 1] where 0 means fully transparent and 1 fully opaque.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.Position
member.summary: Gets or sets the entity position in world space

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.X
member.summary: Gets or sets the world X position (px). 0 is considered to be at the left side of the screen, growing to the right as it increases.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.Y
member.summary: Gets or sets the world Y position in world space. 0 is considered to be at the top side of the screen, growing to down as it increases.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.LocalX
member.summary: Gets or sets the local space X position (px). 0 is considered to be at the left side of the screen, growing to the right as it increases.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.LocalY
member.summary: Gets or sets the local space Y position (px). 0 is considered to be at the top side of the screen, growing to down as it increases.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the entity scale in world space

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.XScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the X scale in world space. It's included in [0, infinity] where 1 represents the original size.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.YScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y scale in world space. It's included in [0, infinity] where 1 represents the original size.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.LocalXScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the X scale in local space. It's included in [0, infinity] where 1 represents the original size.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.LocalYScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the Y scale in local space. It's included in [0, infinity] where 1 represents the original size.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.Rotation
member.summary: Gets or sets the global rotation expressed in its Roll euler angle.

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Graphics.Transform2D.DrawOrder
member.summary: Gets or sets the draw order (%) in world space. It's included in [0, 1] where 0 represents the closest position to the camera, and 1 the farthest. The draw order is also "contained" in layers, so the order on these last ones act prior to this value (i.e. an instance with draw order 1 in GUI layer will be always drawn closer than another one with draw order 0 in Alpha, as GUI layer is before than Alpha one).

member.name: P:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics2D.Collider2D.GroupIndex
member.summary: Gets or sets the group index of the collision
member.remarks: The GroupIndex flag of a collider can be used to override the category and mask settings. As the name implies it can be useful to group together fixtures that should either always collide, or never collide. The groupIndex is used as a signed integer instead of a bitflag. Here's how it works - read it slowly because it can be a bit confusing at first. When checking two fixtures to see if they should collide: - If either fixture has a groupIndex of zero, use the category/mask rules as above - If both groupIndex values are non-zero but different, use the category/mask rules as above - If both groupIndex values are the same and positive, collide - If both groupIndex values are the same and negative, don't collide

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics2D.RopeJoint2D
member.summary: A rope joint enforces a maximum distance between two points on two bodies. It has no other effect.
member.remarks: Warning: if you attempt to change the maximum length during the simulation you will get some non-physical behavior. A model that would allow you to dynamically modify the length would have some sponginess, so I chose not to implement it that way. See b2DistanceJoint if you want to dynamically control length.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics2D.MouseJoint2D
member.summary: A mouse joint is used to make a point on a body track a specified world point. This a soft constraint with a maximum force. This allows the constraint to stretch and without applying huge forces. NOTE: this joint is not documented in the manual because it was developed to be used in the testbed. If you want to learn how to use the mouse joint, look at the testbed.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics2D.RevoluteJoint2D
member.summary: A revolute joint constrains two bodies to share a common point while they are free to rotate about the point. The relative rotation about the shared point is the joint angle. You can limit the relative rotation with a joint limit that specifies a lower and upper angle. You can use a motor to drive the relative rotation about the shared point. A maximum motor torque is provided so that infinite forces are not generated.

member.summary: Rigidbody2D enable your entities to act under the control of physics. The Rigidbody can receive forces and torque to make your objects move in a realistic way. Any entity must contain a Rigidbody to be influenced by gravity, act under added forces or interact with other objects through physics engine.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics3D.BallSocketJoint3D
member.summary: The BallSocketJoint restricts all three linear degrees of freedom. Each entity has a point attached and the constraint attempts to keep the two points at the same location. BallSocketJoints are very common and act as the linear component of many constraint configurations. For example, in a ragdoll, every joint has a BallSocketJoint to keep the body together (along with other constraints to handle angular motion).

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics3D.FixedJoint3D
member.summary: The FixedJoints restricts one angular degree of freedom. Each entity has an axis attached and the constraint attempts to prevent any relative twisting motion around the axes. FixedJoints have a singularity that can cause instability when the axes are folded back onto themselves. Prevent this configuration from occurring using other limits or by ensuring the connected physical entities will collide before it can happen.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics3D.RigidBody3D
member.summary: Rigidbody3D enable your entities to act under the control of physics. The Rigidbody can receive forces and torque to make your objects move in a realistic way. Any entity must contain a Rigidbody to be influenced by gravity, act under added forces or interact with other objects through physics engine.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics3D.SwivelHingeJoint3D
member.summary: The SwivelHingeJoint allows two angular degrees of freedom between two entities. It is comprised of a BallSocketJoint and a SwivelHingeAngularJoint. The joint also provides control over the free degrees of freedom through its RevoluteLimit, RevoluteMotor, TwistLimit, and TwistMotor which are initially inactive.

member.name: T:WaveEngine.Framework.Physics3D.UniversalJoint3D
member.summary: The UniversalJoint allows two angular degrees of freedom between two entities. It is comprised of a BallSocketJoint and a TwistJoint. Its useful for transferring twist motion around angles, such as in vehicle drive shafts. The UniversalJoint also provides a TwistLimit and TwistMotor which are initially inactive. These are not complementary to the TwistJoint; the TwistJoint should be inactive if either the limit or motor is active.

member.summary: Number of bits that have been returned.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the Seed

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.remarks: The initial seed depends on the time.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with a given seed.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.Initialize
member.summary: Allow to execute custom logic during the initialization of this instance.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.Terminate
member.summary: Allow to execute custom logic during the finalization of this instance.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.Reinitialise(System.Int32)
member.summary: Reinitialises this instance with the specified seed.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.Next
member.summary: Generates a random int over the range 0 to int.MaxValue-1.
member.remarks: MaxValue is not generated in order to remain functionally equivalent to System.Random.Next(). This does slightly eat into some of the performance gain over System.Random, but not much. For better performance see: Call NextInt() for an int over the range 0 to int.MaxValue. Call NextUInt() and cast the result to an int to generate an int over the full Int32 value range including negative values.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to zero and less than .

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.Next(System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a random int over the range 0 to upperBound-1, and not including upperBound.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to zero and less than upperBound.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.Next(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Generates a random int over the range lowerBound to upperBound-1, and not including upperBound. upperBound must be >= lowerBound. lowerBound may be negative.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to lowerBound and less than upperBound.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.NextDouble
member.summary: Generates a random double between 0.0 and 1.0, not including 1.0.
member.returns: A double-precision floating point number greater than or equal to 0.0, and less than 1.0.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.NextBytes(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Fills the provided byte array with random bytes.
member.remarks: This method is functionally equivalent to System.Random.NextBytes().
member.param: An array of bytes to contain random numbers.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.NextUInt
member.summary: Generates a uint. Values returned are over the full range of a uint, uint.MinValue to uint.MaxValue, inclusive.
member.remarks: This is the fastest method for generating a single random number because the underlying random number generator algorithm generates 32 random bits that can be cast directly to a uint.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to zero and less or equal than .

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.NextInt
member.summary: Generates a random int over the range 0 to int.MaxValue, both inclusive.
member.remarks: This method differs from Next() only in that the range is 0 to int.MaxValue and not 0 to int.MaxValue-1. The slight difference in range means this method is slightly faster than Next() but is not functionally equivalent to System.Random.Next().
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to zero and less or equal than .

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.NextBool
member.remarks: This method's performance is improved by generating 32 bits in one operation and storing them ready for future calls.

member.name: M:WaveEngine.Framework.Services.FastRandom.NextBool(System.Single)
member.summary: Generates a single random bit with True value weight.
member.param: The weight of the TRUE value
